column8: A Deeply Moving and Unforgettable Spiritual Experience
column11: Visiting Kataragama Temple was one of the most powerful and memorable parts of my journey through Sri Lanka. This sacred site is unlike any other — a rare place where multiple faiths come together in harmony. Buddhists, Hindus, and even local Muslims and Veddas all revere this place, and you can feel that deep spiritual energy the moment you enter. The daily rituals, rhythmic drumming, incense, and devotion of the pilgrims create a truly immersive experience. Watching devotees carry kavadi offerings or bathe in the Menik Ganga was humbling and beautiful. The temple grounds are expansive yet peaceful, especially early in the morning or just before dusk. Even as a non-religious visitor, I felt welcomed and deeply moved. The blend of nature, tradition, and raw human faith here is hard to put into words — it’s something you feel. Yes, there are vendors and crowds during festivals, but that’s part of the living culture. Come with respect, dress modestly, and don’t rush. Let the place speak to you.

column8: The holy site of Kataragama Srilankia
column11: A temple for all faiths The holy site of Kataragama, nestled on the banks of the Menik Ganga, close to the Yala Wildlife Reserve, and in the deep southeast of Sri Lanka, is a site of frequent and popular pilgrimage by Buddhists, Hindus, Muslims, and even Christians. Rich in historical associations and legends, Katargama is tightly woven with its deity – Skandha, the God of War. The worship of God Skandha takes many forms, the culmination of which manifests in the annual Esala Festival and Perahera, itself a spectacle with many rituals. A land where all religions of the country meet, Kataragama contains multiple sites of note, including spiritual sites such as the Kiri Vehera and various temples and kovils dedicated to various deities, as well as natural attractions such as the nearby Yala National Park and Menik Ganga

Its my visit to Kataragama, with my family visiting religious places in Sri Lanka. Kataragama is a multi religious sacred city for Buddhists, Tamils, and the Muslims. Its a sacred city for anyone to visit, with Buddhist temples, Hindu Temples, and a Mosque. Many pilgrims visit Kataragama to offer their rituals, and grant their gratitude to any gods they promised an offering of flowers, gifts or any other vows they have made to offer the gods. Many pilgrims visit Kataragama around the year, but many visit in July/August. Its in August that the Kataragama Perehera or the festival is a possession of Elephants, Dancers, Whip Crackers and many more attractions are found during this possession. If you want to pay your rituals what you have kept, its better to prepare your flower baskets, fruit tray from home. So that they are fresh and not damaged or crushed. If you want to buy flowers or fruits at the entrance from the stalls outside you will be cheated or you will end up paying more than expected. Not like those days, now its all business, these scammers will scrape all your money with rotten fruits, beautifully arranged, so you need to be careful, and eating around you should find the correct place to eat and drink. As you make get allergies, its better to have mineral water through out the day. If you are to visit the temples, kovils, or the mosque, the best time will  be early morning around 5 am, or in the late evening after 5 pm, as you wont feel the hot climate. If you are looking for a comfortable place to stay, there are many guest houses, hotels, or houses that rent out rooms. If you can find a place close by to the Kataragama sacred area, it will be convenient.  You need not worry looking for parking spaces, just walk it out you will be fresh and comfortable. The room prices are reasonable during the off season, and no need to worry about the crowd. During the months of June and August you will need to book your room in advance. If you re to book online, search and find the correct place, as you will not end up paying extra. Travelling to Kataragama, you can travel by your own car, hired vehicles, or take the local transport (bus). You can take the Colombo - Kataragama route, Nuwara  Eliya - Kataragama route, Badulla - Kataragama - route. If you are planning to take the Buttala road, there are some precautions you need to take. The Tissamaharama road is safe, but the Buttala road you have to drive carefully, on the way you will cross the Yala forest area, and there are elephants on the road in three or four places. They stand by the road side to get fruits from the travelers passing by. So travelers usually take fruits, (bananas, mangos, pineapples to feed them in case they come across one. Usually they can be seen in the morning hours, afternoon, or in the evenings.  They will not attack or disturb you, unless you don't disturb them. But, recently they were some incidents, where the elephants had attacked some vehicles, and damaged. There were some foreign tourists who were attacked by the elephants and damaged the vehicle they had hired. The wild life authorities were at the area to find out the reason for the attack. They found out that some you tubers/ scammers had aroused the elephants to attack the passing vehicles. When the elephants attack we leave out vehicles, valuables and flee for safety. At this moment the scammers/ you tubers take the opportunity to record the incident as a natural attack and post it on their youtube accounts, and the valuable that are left in the cars or left on the road are robbed. (Its was a news flash on the TV channels in SriLanka two weeks back). Now they say the wild life has put a stop and controlled the situation. What ever it is, its better to be cautious and be safe. If you ever see a biker with a phone on the Buttala road, that means there is an elephant ahead on the road, and is on a wage to attack. Don't get closer or pass the biker, just stop for a moment, if the area is clear, then proceed. This is a note for your safety. Drive safe, be cautious and enjoy the trip. Hope you have a safe journey. See you soon. "Flavorful Destinations" By:- M N Nizam

column8: Co-existence of the Buddhists, Hindus, Muslims and the Vedda
column11: A religious complex still venerated by the Buddhists, Hindus, Muslims and the Vedda, all who manage their respective shrines amid the legends and myths of a long-held belief in a Sacred City. It lies on a scenic rock overhang above the Tamarind Lake. The complex has many different parts; mosque, temple, shrines, stupas, giant statue, areas of contemplation and gardens. With some of the surrounding history going back to the 1stC. It was a great learning experience to understand how all these different denominations could coexist in such a profound way.

One of the greatest kings in Sri Lanka, King Dutugemunu, organized his tropps in Katharagama area for the legendary "Magampura" battle between King Dutugemunu and the rival king Elara (who invaded a part of the North Central province and claimed as the ruler) before he went to battle and United the country under one flag and United Nation Just before he commenced marching from south to the the North Central to fight the invader, he made a promise to God Katharama asking for his blessings and shot his arrow into the sky.  The promise was to build a temple for God Katharama at the point where the arrow landed (Dadubasna manaya).  He wan the battle, build a temple and crowned at the Ruwanweli maha seya in Anuradhapura in North Central province. From that day onwards, Katharaga Temple has been a prime pilgrim location for the majority of people irrespective of their religion and it has service many rulers , even recent years, to win battle against characters who tried to claim a part of our motherland.

A group of six of us, after visiting Kirivehera, entered the historical Katharagama Devalaya from the northern entrance in the evening on 11th February 2019, after leaving our footwear with the caretaker.  The most important in this temple complex is the main shrine dedicated to the guardian deity with six faces and twelwe arms sitting on a peacock, the “Katharagama Deviyo” also venerated by Hindus as “Murugan or Skanda”.  This main shrine attracts Buddhist as well as Hindu pilgrims from all over Sri Lanka and from as far as South India. As we had adequate time before the pooja (offering) scheduled for 1900 hrs, we walked around the temple complex visiting the other subordinate shrines dedicated to deities Vishnu, Ganesha, Dedimunda, Paththini, Kali, Suniyam and Sumana Saman.  The bo tree behind the main Katharagama shrine is said to be a sapling from the Anuradhapura bodhi tree planted in 3rd Century BCE.  We could walk around leisurely and amongst the seated devotees since it was a weekday and not not so crowded.  Weekends and full-moon days see throngs of people visiting the temple. Some of us, carrying our offerings of fruits in a tray, joined the queue with other devotees.  The queue at the left was for those with tray offerings and the one on the right for others.  Those with tray offerings keep clearly visible monetary offerings on top of the fruit tray demonstrating their piety and seeking divine intervention into or from whatever problems they may have.  Others seek fulfilment of their wishes and aspirations.  After the main official pooja, these trays are accepted by the priests chanting prayers interceding for devotees, part emptied and returned to the owners.  At the exit, you may opt to have a dot placed on your forehead signifying obeisance and reverence. Unlike at other temples, the main shrine is a simple two roomed structure, not at all grand.  The other surrounding shrines too are in simple one roomed buildings, some built from stone.  I understand that they had not been altered since they were built as people are reluctant to carry out modifications.  Furthermore, in all these shrine rooms, the deities are not represented by large statues, but by large drawings portraying their glory and power.  Within the main shrine, in addition to the main drawing facing the entrance are few others on side walls too depicting the power of Katharagama deity.  With the sounding of many bells at this sacred place, coupled with the chanting, the aura of the Katharagama guardian deity descended on me, overwhelming me, when within the shrine.  The feelings each of us experience may of course vary depending on our beliefs and the environment. Almost as one enters through main entrance is the coconut breaking area situated right in front of the main Katharagama Devala.  Devotees hold the coconut with both hands raised, make a prayer or a wish, and dash it on the stone basin, breaking it into pieces and spilling its water.  They believe that this helps their wish and prayer to come true.  Some do wish ill-will to their enemies when shattering the coconut. After exiting the temple through the main southern entrance around 8.00 pm, we walked along the road leading to and across the Menik river.  We observed people bathing in the river even at this late hour.  There is a saying among the locals that if you bathe in this river all your sins get washed away!!

Kataragama a popular pilgrimage destination frequented by all three religious groups Buddhists, Hindus and Muslims in Sri Lanka. The main shrine devoted to Skanda popularly described in eulogies as God having six faces and twelve arms whose assistance is sought for worldly gain. The history of the shrine dates back to 2 century BC. The annual procession held in July or August is the main event of the shrine with fire walkers and Kawadi dancers. It is close to the beach areas of Hambantota and the jungles of Yala National Park.

Super crowded location may cause tiring or lost in the crowd. So, better avoiding perehera season if you want to explore the place leisurely. There are plenty of small stalls to buy flowers, fruits baskets and also mouth-watering sweet and savory snacks. In my recent visit to Sri Lanka one of the places I wanted to visit was Kataragama  temple. Despite pre warnings from my family I have decided to take '"puja thattu" (offering to the gods). After paying Rs 1000 for some fruits (at least some earning for the locals). I had to queue up for an hour in the heat to enter the temple. Expectations were high so it did not matter to me and also enjoyed the chats with the people who travelled from villages hundreds of miles away who had come to this sacred place expecting miracles and probably spent most of their earnings. After one hour we were allowed to enter the temple and what I saw on the temple stage shocked me. There were three fat men dressed in white (called kapuas) directed the people with the offerings to a man behind the curtain. When I gave my offering plus Rs 1000 note (common practise) he put the money in one place and took half of the fruits and gave me the balance as blessed by Lord Murugan. I did not see any blessing going in there or at least blessing me. I am sure that the same expectations were with the others who had being in the queue for hours. How can one turn a place of worship to something like this? At least spend few minutes to bless each person to make their long journey to this sacred place worth while.

Katirkāmam Murukaṉ Kōyil') in Kataragama, Sri Lanka, is a temple complex dedicated to Buddhist guardian deity Kataragama deviyo and Hindu War God Kathirkamam. We visited Kataragama Temple complex on a Sunday when local people visit in their thousands. Our Driver/Guide found place in front of stall outside of the complex, where we purchased a plate of offering in the form of fruit for the Hindu Temple. Then as we were walking to the temple entrance, we witnessed many people bathing in a very dirty river before entering the temple. Along the long path to the temple complex there are stalls selling fruit, flowers and incense. There are large groups of black-faced monkeys on all of the trees waiting for the fruit to be given to them after the temple blessing. As usual, there are many starving dogs, some with extremely bad skin conditions roaming the path or the temple complex. Also, there are quite a few beggar families who send their children to beg from the devotees. There are three places of worship at this complex, with the Hindu Temple being the main focus and then the Buddhist Temple and finally the Mosque. Many people visit both the Hindu Temple and the Buddhist Temple and give offerings. We purchased a plate of fruit as offering and proceeded to wait in line for at least for at least one-hour for the temple to open. While we were waiting, we witnessed two different processions to the temple with music and dancing. Once the temple opened the process of getting the blessing and walking out with your blessed fruit was a little chaotic. Then, as we had purchased and brought with us dog food for the stray starving dogs, we proceeded to feed the hungriest dogs with our food. Then we walked the path to the Buddhist Temple, feeding some of the monkeys our blessed fruit by leaving it on tree branches. At the Buddhist Temple, we witnessed people being provided food in a large hall. The saddest thing we witnessed was the Temple Elephant. OMG! They had the Temple Elephant tied to a fence with absolutely no room for it to move, so that it was forced to endure standing in the heat, in its own excrement, while people paid money to walk under its belly. Apparently these STUPID people believe that by walking under the belly of a Temple Elephant, they are absolved of all of their sins. Why is this abomination still allowed to happen in Sri Lanka and especially in a Buddhist Temple? Please people of Sri Lanka – you can stop this continuing. I saw the Elephant continuously shedding tears while I was there watching this madness going on. I pointed the tears out to the Mahout, who just brushed it aside saying it is normal behaviour. I really wish that my review will bring to light the plight of this Temple Elephant and the Sri Lankan people themselves will choose to stop this form of exploitation of this Elephant from continuing.

Kataragamam temple (Sinhalese Katharagama; Tamil Katirkāmam) in Kataragama, Sri Lanka, is a temple complex dedicated to Kataragama deviyo. It is one of the few religious sites in Sri Lanka that is venerated by the Sinhala Buddhists, Hindu Sri Lankan Tamils, Sri Lankan Moors and the Vedda people.[3] It is a collection of modest shrines, of which the one dedicated to Kataragama deviyo, is the most important. Kri Vehera (Buddhist Temple) Maha devale (Hindu shrine), Shiva kovil and ul-Khizr mosque are located within the sacred city of Kataragama. Kataragama God is indigenous to Sri Lanka and was named after the town in which his shrine was situated. Avoid visiting the place especially on long weekends as the place is heavily crowded. The best times to visit the Maha Devale is during the Pooja Times which is 5.00 am, 10.30am and 7.00pm. On Saturdays the Morning 5.00am pooja is not held.

I went Kataraama and visited few religious places during the last week end (10th and 11th of Sep, 2016). There were more people at the place, may be due to the long weekend for the public sector employees. The area was very dry since this is not the rainy season there. The history of this place goes to the era of King Dutugemunu who ruled the country during the period of 161 BC - 137 BC. According to the history the tusks of his royal tusker, "Kandula" are also placed at this location. But those are not exhibit for the general public. There are many people in the island who keep the trust on god Kataragama. This place considered as one of the main worship place for that god. Therefore many people irrespective of their religion visit this devala with the expectation of the blessing of god Kataragama. The other well known worship placed for god Kataragama are, "Sellakataragama" and "Kebiliththa". It is better of you can avoid week ends to visit there, if you need to avoid the crowd.

The temple is apparently a famous one, with many Hindus making months long pilgrimages to the temple. Fortunately, it was off season for pilgrimages! Even then, there was a good size of devotees with only a handful or so of tourists. The surrounds are quite large. Starting from the town itself, there are stalls selling all manner of religious paraphernalia. You walk across a river, with people bathing in it on hot days. You pass a mobile phone tower disguised (badly) as a tree. Finally you get to the temple precinct. The area is large, with a massive bodhi tree set behind the central core. The central core is where most of the action was when we were there. Regrettably, even at 10am, that means doing the hot bare foot shuffle or running from one scant shade to the next - This was the trying bit. We also checked out the museum on the grounds. Now, this was worth the visit although it seems under-visited. Lots of original and replica statues and ancient implements. One of the best things was, despite the inevitable beggars, we did not feel harassed by anyone trying to sell us anything.

Kataragam for some inexplicable reasons misses the attention and due recognition it deserves in the tourists maps. Religiously, it has claims / references from three major religions. Hindus and Muslims believe it is the place where Lord Skanda / Prophet Khdir lived. Therefore visiting the Hindu shrines and the mosque is a must but without forgetting the nearby “ Kiri Vehera “ where it is believed to containing one of the relics of Lord Buddha thus highly revered. Religious rituals are performed daily once in the Morning and once in the evening at the Hindu shrine which is a bit lengthy for a casual visitor. But if you have qualified guide / assistant to take you through the meanings of all the rituals, it would be a wonderful experience. Do not forget to partake in the divine offering being given out after each Puja, which is made of rice, green grams, jiggery, plums, cashew etc. Finally, to have a Tilaka (Ash dot) on your forehead (Third eye) will relieve all your fatigue after travelling and helps your broaden one’s wisdom too.

The history says “Lord Gauthama Buddha” visited Kataragama in his 3rd visit to Sri Lanka and met king Mahasena, later the king built Kiri Vehera Dagaba on the ground where Buddha had meditated, in 580 BC. However, there are many legends around this and some believe it was built by “King Parakkramabhahu the Great” in Polonnaruwa in 300 BC. All Buddhists who visit Kataragama  worship Kiri Vehera Dagaba as it is one of the “Solosmasthana”, the 16 pilgrimage sites of important to worship in Sri Lanka. Buddhists in Sri Lanka believe Kataragama is a holly place blessed by Buddha, hence visited throughout the year. Most of the Sri Lankan Buddhists used to visit Kataragama,   once a year to obtain the blessings of “God Kataragama” who supposed to be the guardian of the Buddhism in Sri Lanka. It was told that this dagaba was built protecting the “Golden Seat” the Buddha sat on during his sermon, “Buddha’s hair” and also the “Royal Sward” which “Prince Siddhartha” used to cut his hair near “Anoma” river in India at the time he abandon his life as a prince.

It is a pilgrimage town sacred to South Indians, Buddhists, Hindus and indigenous Veddas. Pure Buddhists would not believe in Gods, but since Sri Lanka is influenced by a lot of Hindu Customs and Rituals, people show great reverence to God Kataragama. Buddhists would usually visit the Kirivehera to pay their respects to the Buddha first, before walking down the sandy road to the Katharamaga Kovil. Many people still bath at the Menik Ganga (River) and wear white and desist from eating meat/ consuming alcohol prior to entering the sacred compound. Folklore: Katharagama God came in the guise of an old man and asked the first person he met (who happened to be a Tamil) to build him a house. This person assessed the old man, and asked him why he should waste time building a house for an old man who will die soon.The next person he met (who happened to be a Sinhalese) was asked the same question. The Sinhalese man agreed to build the old man a house. This is the reason for rituals in the kovil to be performed by only Sinhalese people, whereas kovils of other Gods have Tamil Poosaris. People also believe that Tamils need to show penance and perform various activities such as rolling bare bodied on the sad, piercing their mouths, piercing their skin and hanging themselves from a rope etc. The logs we see above the entrance to the kovil is said to be the same wood used to make the original house of Katharagama God. The location of the house was marked by the God by shooting an arrow from Vadihiti Kanda. The Bo tree behind the Kataragama temple is one of the eight saplings of the Sri Maha Bodhiya in Anuradapura. The best time to visit is early morning (I think the pooja is at 4.30am). The sand and the air are cool and there is much less crowd. Prepare for large crowds during weekends/ holidays. December was a good time for our visit. The vegetation was green and air cool and clean.

Visited this very large and well known temple complex on a very hot day and wished we'd had thick hiking socks on.  Tip we'd had from our driver on any day we were visiting temples was to wear socks, and one of us had forgotten completely, the other had thin ones on.  There are a lot of stalls selling things on the way in for offerings and so forth, and one of them should stock socks for unwary tourists!  There's a walk in and then you reach the hut where you leave your shoes and hats - it's quite a way from there across hot sandy grit to the actual temples and it was seriously burning that day.  Some visitors must have been laughing at the antics trying to touch down as little as possible.  It's a bit different, in that there are multiple temples and a sacred bo tree and various things going on all at once.  Apparently it's a regular place of pilgrimage and where a lot of Sri Lankans bring their new cars for their first outing and hang copies of the registration plates on tree to ensure safe and trouble free driving - understandable when you see the traffic in Colombo!  In one Hindu temple our foreheads were marked and we went around a few closer by, before the feet got too sore and I stayed in the shade of the bo tree watching a couple with two youngsters making their offerings there, circling the tree with pots of water, while husband and driver went to the farthest temple.  By the time they returned there were a group of people dancing in front of the first temple, which we stayed to watch, before leaping as fast as possible back across the sand to the shoe hut.  An interesting experience and worth a visit if you're interested in different cultures and faiths - but don't forget the socks!

People visit Kataragama for a multitude of reasons, out of veneration, to see a facet of religeous culture, pilgrimage, tourist on site seeing etc. Kataragama is in the deep South of Sri Lanka and borders the Yala sanctuary a world renowned place for elephant, leopard, bear, deer peacock, migrant birds and other wildlife. Yala borders the Indian ocean. Kataragama is mainly venerated by Buddhists and Hindus as both pay homage to the Deity Lord Skanda ( Kataramama Deviyo/ God Kataragama). There are  two places of veneration in Kataragama - the Maha Devale of  Lord Skanda and the Kiri Vehera.   Buddhists first worship Kiri Vehera, a dagoba of great magnitude and serenity to offer flowers, light lamps, incense, then prey and meditate and thereafter proceed to Kataragama Maha Devale / Kovil on a walkway that joins the two places of worship. Kataragama Maha viharaya is visited by all religions in Sri Lanka, Buddhist, Hindu, Christian, Muslim etc, during the pooja times, when beels are rung incense is lit, invocations are made and alms specially prepared by devotees on a 365 day roster are brought amidst ceremony. It is a sight to behold and an experience for the mind. The precincts of the Maha Devale is also home to other shrines,a sacred bo tree, and a properly organized pilgrim would earn merits for himself by visiting all these places of worship, which even includes a muslim mosque.

You can arrange for fruit baskets to offer as blessings at various shops nearby, and they will carry it for you from the car park/shops, across the river to the Devale. However you can also get a police permit to drive over a (very) narrow bridge behind the devale and park closer.
